title: 111_hr2134
content: The Act may be cited as the "Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009". Congress finds that in 2008, there were millions of users of marijuana, cocaine, methamphetamine, and heroin in the United States. The majority of cocaine and heroin in the US originates from Andean countries and Colombia and Mexico, respectively. Drug trafficking from Colombia and Mexico generates violence, instability, and corruption. In Central America, Mexico, Venezuela, Ecuador, Haiti, and the Caribbean, organized criminals use drug trafficking to threaten law enforcement, political institutions, and citizen security. Drug-related violence is increasing in Mexico. Drug-related violence is escalating in Mexico and along the United States-Mexico border, with 5,661 deaths in 2008 alone. Organized criminal networks in Mexico traffic women and girls into the United States for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups and their supporters pose a threat in the Western region. Mexico traffics women and girls into the US for sexual exploitation. Extremist groups like FARC and Hezbollah use drug trafficking to fund terrorism. US counternarcotics assistance to Latin America and the Caribbean totaled $11.3 billion from 1980-2008. Establishment of the Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission to review and evaluate US policies on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction in the Western Hemisphere. The Commission will identify options to improve international and domestic counternarcotics policies. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will review US policies on illicit drug supply reduction and interdiction, including international control policies, interdiction efforts, crop eradication programs, and economic development alternatives. The impact of the Andean Counterdrug Initiative will also be assessed. The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission will assess the impact of various initiatives in curbing drug production, trafficking, and violence. This includes evaluating the use of technology against drug cartels and efforts to prevent the trafficking of chemical precursors. An assessment will be conducted on efforts to curb the trafficking of chemical precursors for illicit drugs, the United States drug certification process, the demand for illicit drugs in the United States population, and drug prevention and treatment programs. The assessment includes evaluating the extent of illicit drug consumption driven by addiction, effective treatment experiences, and recommendations to improve US policies on reducing drug supply and demand. The Commission will assess the value of supporting government and nongovernmental institutions in the Western Hemisphere to reduce illicit drug supply and demand, and evaluate the indicators of success in US drug control policy. Coordination with governments, international organizations, and NGOs in the region is required for the review. The Commission will consult with government, academic, and nongovernmental leaders in the Western Hemisphere, as well as the Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission (CICAD) to enhance effectiveness. A report must be submitted within 12 months of the first meeting. The Commission will consult with various stakeholders in the Western Hemisphere to enhance effectiveness and submit a report to relevant committees within 12 months. The Commission will submit a report to relevant committees within 12 months, detailing recommendations, findings, and conclusions, including input from consulted leaders and organizations. The Commission will submit a report to relevant committees within 12 months, detailing recommendations, findings, and conclusions, including input from consulted leaders and organizations. The report will be made available to the public. SEC. 6. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of ten members appointed by various leaders, excluding current government officials. Each member serves for the duration of the Commission's existence, with vacancies not affecting its power. The Commission consists of ten members appointed for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled promptly. Members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment, and a Chairperson selected within 60 days for the review and report process. The Commission consists of ten members appointed for the life of the Commission, with vacancies filled promptly. Members must be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment, and a Chairperson selected within 60 days for the review and report process. Six members constitute a quorum, and members receive travel expenses in accordance with specified regulations. The Commission has ten members appointed for its duration, with vacancies filled promptly. Members must be appointed within 30 days, and a Chairperson selected within 60 days. Six members form a quorum, and they receive travel expenses as per regulations. SEC. 7. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold meetings and hearings as needed. It also has access to necessary resources from various government departments to carry out its duties effectively. The Commission has access to resources from government departments for its activities, including office space and administrative support provided by the General Services Administration. The Chairperson can request access in writing when needed. The Commission also has the authority to use the United States mails. The Commission has the authority to use the United States mails and enter into contracts for necessary activities. The Commission has the authority to enter into contracts for necessary activities, but any agreement cannot extend beyond the termination date of the Commission. SEC. 8. STAFF. The Commission shall have an Executive Director who can appoint necessary staff paid at a rate not exceeding level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission may appoint additional personnel without following standard appointment procedures. The Executive Director of the Commission can appoint staff under title 5, United States Code, without following standard procedures. Temporary services can be procured with approval, and government employees can be detailed upon request. The Executive Director can appoint staff under title 5, United States Code, and procure temporary services. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission without affecting their civil service status. SEC. 9. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000 authorized to carry out the Act, available without fiscal year limitation. SEC. 10. Sunset: The Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission terminates 60 days after submitting its report to Congress.
